title: English Language Arts: Grade 4
subject: English Language Arts and Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects (2024-)

document.title: Iowa Academic Standards for English Language Arts and Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects

7A89989901E6488FBD81F7B3C4A0782C.description:
Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and
phrases, including those that signal precise actions, emotions, or states of being (e.g., quizzed, whined,
stammered) and that are basic to a particular topic (e.g., wildlife, conservation, and endangered when
discussing animal preservation).

4B0D9CBEA63246D08A869F9F1BA5C42F.description: Demonstrate an understanding of synonyms and antonyms.

E90AF28569CC471CA39733EFB106281D.description: Recognize and explain the meaning of common idioms, adages, and proverbs.

C90CF032C88F450B9861E7BD7818B574.description: Explain the meaning of simple similes and metaphors (e.g., as pretty as a picture) in context.

4F2B9782FC8A4C2CBA5FC8D0F3009814.description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

DADF32F2A1C74E30B6AF992450C8C884.description:
Consult reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses) to find the pronunciation
and determine or clarify the precise meaning of key words and phrases.

B8B0BFAE4EFD4E8691F3E5632539BA6B.description:
Use common, grade-appropriate Greek and Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a
word (e.g., telegraph, photograph, autograph).

9FC25C0DDF3A4AFAB3D0B1C03DBEFE8B.description:
Use context (e.g., definitions, examples, or restatements in text) as a clue to the meaning of a
word or phrase.

AB9B1B51CF114790B06B954E0AE5DA1D.description:
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade
4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

5CD3FBFDC3CE4056BE75481BEA288E97.description:
Differentiate between contexts that call for formal English (e.g., presenting ideas) and situations
where informal discourse is appropriate (e.g., small-group discussion).

6F1CDA45A7F941CC85330851AF19CFD3.description: Choose words and phrases to convey ideas precisely.

266B79A10D83486F979E0599E80C0AE5.description: Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

9729E5B1AAE346DB9F4F6576E8CA7DBE.description: Spell correctly, consulting references as needed.

F33119077B2F4A80B04193F438AAA35A.description: Use a comma before a coordinating conjunction in a compound sentence.

A0AC91811A2B4B5CA2E66F173D24DB8F.description: Use commas and quotation marks to mark direct speech and quotations from a text.

6B121DBD5B1348BB961CE2B12866148B.description:
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling
when writing.

77073BB6CB574BE9989B3CEEE45CD0B6.description: Correctly use homophones (e.g., to, too, two, there, their).

C4ABD81DA2314D449324965C2C847C44.description: Produce complete sentences, recognizing and correcting fragments and run-ons.

CDB83204E5CE424CB24B854C484FF9E7.description: Order adjectives within sentences according to conventional patterns.

4AC64993BE3C4F7CA51148F533D26B92.description: Use modal auxiliaries (e.g., can, may, must) to convey various conditions.

8BFE796F1F4A48B09730A0532DA1F1DB.description: Form and use the progressive (e.g., I was walking; I am walking; I will be walking) verb tenses.

E6D5EBEF60644DEF8342BBA88089A39E.description:
Use relative pronouns (who, whose, whom, which, that) and relative adverbs (where, when,
why).

1D14079992964B259C000805E3F976DE.description:
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or
speaking.

453C268CFFD7447B9326FD6D8488F52D.description:
Differentiate between contexts that call for formal English (e.g., presenting ideas, performing dramatic
readings or presentations) and situations where informal discourse is appropriate (e.g., small-group
discussion); use formal English when appropriate to task and situation with eye contact, adequate
volume, and clear pronunciation. (See grade 4 Language standards 1 and 3 for specific expectations)

80B1680E75764DDD8FF68180A02D3B40.description:
Add audio recordings and visual displays to presentations when appropriate to enhance the
development of main ideas or themes.

9FD49E133DB84E5887081AE794C47D88.description:
Report on a topic or text, tell a story, or recount an experience in an organized manner, using
appropriate facts and relevant, descriptive details to support main ideas or themes; speak clearly and at
an understandable pace.

E72E03D7F13B494A8E602C41AE0AB7D6.description: Identify the reasons and evidence a speaker provides to support particular points.

A631ADB893CE45F48282F3BA481C8459.description:
Paraphrase text read aloud or information presented in diverse media, and formats, including visually,
quantitatively, and orally.

88458321F5474E1A8F0E4121B45151F6.description:
Review the key ideas expressed and explain their own ideas and understanding in light of the
discussion.

F37060AD0C8647AE99EB5731CD586D8E.description:
Pose and respond to specific questions to clarify or follow up on information, and make
comments that contribute to the discussion and link to the remarks of others.

6B509C67F05B4334B94F51938E17B467.description: Follow agreed-upon rules for discussions and carry out assigned roles.

EFAAD4387E534EC6AA6DCD8862D34B9C.description:
Come to discussions prepared, having read or studied required material; explicitly draw on that
preparation and other information known about the topic to explore ideas under discussion.

E31933C7A56D4B5EAAACC4678ACE1432.description:
Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with
diverse partners on grade 4 topics and texts, building on others’ ideas and expressing their own clearly.

224F8A09D52D4108980DE91B915638DB.description:
Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time
frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and
audiences.

EA0786656F4C41C482DBCFEEA21CBB8C.description:
Apply grade 4 Reading standards to informational texts (e.g., “Explain how an author uses
reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text”).

84706F3BD8DB4436B0B71A7E892C84DD.description:
Apply grade 4 Reading standards to literature (e.g., “Describe in depth a character, setting, or
event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character’s thoughts,
words, or actions).”).

28C624AFA40B46538C2374AC94EEE098.description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

5E900E60598142BB8CF45B756B32597F.description:
Recall relevant information from experiences or gather relevant information from print and digital
sources; take notes and categorize information, and provide a list of sources.

1E4AC7D576B941BCBCE2A825A22F3A55.description:
Conduct short research projects that build knowledge through investigation of different aspects of a
topic.

904EF2BDAAAA434C947243080D6A0556.description: Research to Build and Present Knowledge

7E2224199FEB41F5814656BA15931306.description:
With some guidance and support from adults, use technology to produce and publish writing as well as
to interact and collaborate with others; demonstrate sufficient command of keyboarding skills.

3A75CDD13CE64BB2A3069D278968C6EF.description:
With guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as needed by
planning, revising, and editing. (Editing for conventions should demonstrate command of Language
standards 1–3 up to and including grade 4.)

24F289FC099448018FA4D0A59D44D198.description:
Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development and organization are appropriate to task,
purpose, and audience. (Grade-specific expectations for writing types are defined in standards 1–3
above.)

CE67E184E02840C387DA82F51EEF2CD8.description: Provide a conclusion that follows from the narrated experiences or events.

1467186567C144B0ABA2D29D757D5AB9.description:
Use concrete words and phrases and sensory details to convey experiences and events
precisely.

2871C3E52C3E4890BDB5696E40484FAD.description: Use a variety of transitional words and phrases to manage the sequence of events.

3C5266AAFF22417DBFB046E08FAE5114.description:
Use dialogue and description to develop experiences and events or show the responses of
characters to situations.

661D6E55CB9B4D44B30D0012DA35D226.description:
Use an organizational structure to orient the reader by establishing a situation and introducing a
narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally.

231F58E96E05454F80FF4D21063B7CE2.description:
Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique,
descriptive details, and clear event sequences.

6DF733E9FA7A4D40ACEDD482E0A1AA2B.description: Provide a concluding statement or section related to the information or explanation presented.

5A54A9AAF9C84CAB8B2A700B3CA9AAE5.description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic.

B63FCE3A72644FC58A2CF9D6DCF2C8B2.description:
Link ideas within categories of information using words and phrases (e.g., another, for example,
also, because).

97223FB4BD2146DD8D3A971C3800EA36.description:
Develop the topic with facts, definitions, details, quotations, or other information and examples
related to the topic.

308B5586727A459FB06988E4B44944C9.description:
Introduce a topic clearly and group related information in paragraphs and sections; include
formatting (e.g., headings), illustrations, and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.

FE668CAD443C4591A694BAB7E52069C7.description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.

CDA9A552B7714CAF867063BC642C2988.description: Provide a concluding statement or section related to the opinion presented.

66969BD3C8EC49D68066CC0B1F88B573.description: Link opinion and reasons using words and phrases (e.g., for instance, in order to, in addition).

1D614F101C314218BDD7F2CC7D9ED8CB.description: Provide reasons that are supported by facts and details.

6309FD6D2BB742D391350F737174C8F2.description:
Introduce a topic or text clearly, state an opinion, and create an organizational structure in which
related ideas are grouped to support the writer’s purpose.

92D0799B750D4508923FB117D30D3814.description: Write an opinion piece, supported by a point of view.

C9DC94C478BD4B259EC399BCF95583D7.description: Apply previous handwriting skills with accuracy and automaticity.

E9CBC3A8AE914028A628DE55553EA466.description: Write legibly for a variety of tasks and purposes.

64821D23DF5A431586FCA9003C19DB38.description:
Orally read grade-level texts (e.g., poetry and prose) with accuracy, automaticity, and expression at an
appropriate rate to support comprehension, self-correcting as necessary.

80A77B685B244A929EECB34D429CA880.description:
Accurately read unfamiliar multisyllabic words in and out of context using sound-spelling
correspondences, syllabication patterns, and morphology (e.g., roots and affixes).

95AE55EC7E874E3F8590263BE14D739F.description: Know and apply grade-level phonics and word analysis skills to support decoding and encoding words.

FCA1A9278F514089B7A11BB3C78012BA.description: Reading and Writing Standards: Foundational Skills

9FB634B363724F5C836FEADCE54BDE7B.description:
By the end of the year, read and comprehend informational texts, including history/social studies,
science, and technical texts, in the grades 4–5 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as
needed at the high end of the range.

0F6D8E9AF7C84DD4B25058BA643F98F5.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

1721AD0D7CB54D4886B49F5DB552B2BD.description:
Integrate information from two texts on the same topic in order to write or speak about the subject
knowledgeably.

520A408AEDE24E2B84526454F8FCF2EA.description: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text.

13738CDF54CD4298824763D584CE3662.description:
Interpret information presented visually, orally, or quantitatively (e.g., in charts, graphs, diagrams, time
lines, animations, or interactive elements on Web pages) and explain how the information contributes to
comprehension of the text.

95CCF1D9561F45B8B2B1EC57B6201035.description:
Compare and contrast a firsthand and secondhand account of the same event or topic; describe the
differences in focus and the information provided.

FB9410158121433598599FE66DD8A0BF.description:
Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events,
ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.

E98DAF0728E741CE9420A8BDA534B572.description:
Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to
a grade 4 topic or subject area.

F66C92E0E6BC4D65BE457E5EB71165DD.description:
Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what
happened and why, based on specific details from the text.

3F90B046F98D495CA5BE969B2D950235.description: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.

C8962DE5757341A6B946CED7E86D587D.description:
Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing
inferences from the text.

B3EFC47684004033B7B1BD0A06A7E162.description:
By the end of the year, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poetry, in the
grades 4–5 text complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding as needed at the high end of the range.
(RL.4.10)

03D9F4098579471E9E8ED0605F7B446A.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

78AB09D0237B4E898DFD43DEEAB21E93.description:
Compare and contrast the treatment of similar themes and topics (e.g., opposition of good and evil) and
patterns of events (e.g., the quest) in literary text.

78A2C2B89CCE40E99F8A33CE642445FA.description:
Make connections between a literary text and a visual/oral presentation of the text (e.g., mood, aspects
of characters, or setting).

08C874A719184E1E955CD5F685B93C08.description:
Compare and contrast the point of view and/or perspective from which different stories are narrated,
including the difference between first- and third-person narrations.

8056EBD496A64B7DA957883411936304.description:
Explain major differences between poems, drama, and prose, and refer to the structural elements of
poems (e.g., verse, rhythm, meter) and drama (e.g., casts of characters, settings, descriptions,
dialogue, stage directions) when writing or speaking about a text.

AAEC5CB00ADC432A97D68F1CB7A39814.description:
Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including those that allude to
significant characters.

B5CB523EFE944E81A474DFE0DE9A8CCA.description:
Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the
text (e.g., a character’s thoughts, words, or actions).

51D9CC88E139412B9E6A5B2B24DD517B.description: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.

ED78C8B3332F41B5A5F3E05FD7826EE8.description:
Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing
inferences.
